In writing this I have written from the mind having of a member of my family house held at and from 1884 until 1966.

Houses in question during of remembrance of the house on the main street, was their famous every day visited and visited by the old timers.

Every evening dinner and dinner was served at the old house which was owned by the old man and his wife who owned the house.

Did you visit your own house for portraits? How did you mind it? Write a brief note for others.
In writing this, I have written from the stand point of a member of my mother's house held as it was from 1884 until 1906. However in question is never to be home, as the main thing I remember of the best early Christmas days were that Santa always visited and filled the stockings of my sister and I. There was usually a lot each with nuts, candy etc.
In writing this, I have written from the standpoint of a member of my mother's household as I was from 1884 until 1906. However in question 18 I reverted to my own home, as the main thing I remember of the very early Christmas days, was that Santa always visited and filled the stockings of my sister and I. There was usually a holly bush with nuts and candy etc.
Hanna, R. Ida
Keystown, 1884

19. How did you get your Christmas dinner? List how present was prepared and served at that time.

Our second year in our own home

Povesh: Povesh children, choosing "poor" potatoes, carrots, pickles (for sauce), heart pudding, sugar, raisins, nuts, candy, yams, prunes, George Hannah's Mop, Hanna's 26, and two guinea pigs. We had them for a while.

Locally produced foods: Olive Bellinis.
The main change in handling of food has been the packaging of dry goods in metal cans to be used in field hospitals by personnel carrying them to the wounded and those undergoing surgery.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earlier days compared with today.

Present day cooking utensils are much lighter and more easily handled, and the newly introduced ones quicker and more efficient in burning/assimilating fuel. Use of gas, electricity, and oil reduces the heat of cook stoves in summer, reduces the heat of kitchens.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

We still prefer our own home grown vegetables, when we can grow them; also buy eggs and make our own butter. We've bought quite a bit of bread in local stores but still bake new times as often as before.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in your area during pioneer days in eastern Canada.

In the early days vegetables were usually stored in cellars or sometimes root houses if yield of garden was the normal amount of meat because harvests till canning of fresh beans and later quick freeze beans in early days of the year and shortages in early days of the year.

As to shortages in early days of the year was poor, so many were for winter, and practically no vegetables although often not enough potatoes, although after 1887 I think we always had some. In that case canned tomatoes were used more than anything else to help out.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the past.

Poveshull day cooking utensils are much lighter and more easily handled, and the usual new ones quicker and more efficient in burning charcoal elements. Use of gas furnaces and oil or kerosene in burners reduces the heat of the kitchen.

21. What did you begin to rely on pure and proper foods instead of canned and preserved foods? (Give as many details and things as possible.)

We will have our own home grown vegetables when we can grow them; also buy cream and make our own butter. We've bought quite a bit of bread in local stores but take every chance to make our own bread as often as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and purchasing foods in other places, quality, methods of preserving, prices, etc., if more space is needed.

In early days vegetables were usually stored in cellar or sometimes root house. If yield of garden was the normal amount of meal became hard to find. Summer meal storage was the usual method of canning or freeze plants. As to shortages in early days of the year and later quick freeze plants, it meant practically no vegetables at all through after harvest not enough potatoes, although after 1887 I think we always had some in that case canned tomatoes were used more than anything else to help out.
